title: Who invented bills and debt? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most hunter-gatherer societies worked on some kind of system of reciprocity, where everyone knew everyone else, and you were expected to share with whoever needed something. Still, I’m willing to bet that, at some point, in some society, people had enough of a sense of property that some guy gave someone else a hand axe, based on the promise that he’d get a rabbit in return, once the recipient managed to catch one. We’ll never know who the first person to do this was, but he, or she, invented debt. Of course, I’m absolutely certain that the concept emerged in multiple places independently, so the first person to get there isn’t that important. For bills, we have to await the creation of the written word. Once people started to gather into settlements larger than around 150–200 people, you could no longer know everyone around you well enough to deal with them based on relationships alone. Transactions became increasingly important, with a clear agreement about what was being exchanged. Sumer was among the first known civilizations, and they created one of the first known writing systems. Interestingly, the oldest Sumerian documents that we’ve translated are mostly records of transactions. Someone traded a goat to someone else in exchange for so many bushels of wheat. As far as we can tell, when humans figured out how to write, the first thing we wanted to do with it was finance. Now, we don’t know, for sure, how these transactions were completed, but it’s reasonable to assume that, if one party couldn’t fulfill their part of the bargain right away, the record would act as an agreement to pay at a later time, which could be produced to demand payment when that time arrived. In other words, as soon as writing existed, bills existed, it was just on clay tablets.
